clinical_study.brief_title: Normal Values for 3D High Resolution Anorectal Manometry in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Anorectal Area in Children Using 3D High Resolution Anorectal Manometry.

brief_summary.textblock:
Anorectal 3D high resolution manometry (3D HRM) is the most advanced version of manometry equipment and has been recently introduced into clinical practice. It is the most precise method to assess the anal sphincter pressure function and may be crucial for planning and controlling surgical procedures of the anorectal area. Normal values in pediatric population have not been established.
The aim of this study is complex evaluation of anorectal function in children without symptoms from lower GI tract and establishment of normal values.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean and maximum sphincters pressures during rest, voluntary squeeze and bear down maneuvers and Asymmetry of the anal canal
primary_outcome.description: Pressures during voluntary maneuvers will be obtained if cooperation with a child will be possible

secondary_outcome.description: Amount of air in a balloon needed to elicit Rectoanal Inhibitory Reflex
Percent of children without constipation but with dyssynergic defecation pattern

secondary_outcome.measure: Presence of discomfort during the procedure

arm_group.description: All children will be investigated by 3D high resolution anorectal manometry procedure

intervention.description: Procedure will take about 15 min. During procedure resting, voluntary squeeze, bear down maneuver, cough reflex, ano-anal reflex and Rectoanal Inhibitory Reflex will be obtained, if possible.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- parental agreement
- age: 1 to 18 yr
Exclusion Criteria:
- parental disagreement
- children younger than 1 yr
- children after the surgery for anorectal malformations
- children with constipation during the last 10 months
- children with nonretentive fecal soiling
- children with inflammatory bowel diseases or any other type of large bowel inflammation
- children with anal fissure, anal varices, inflammation of the anorectal area or any other disease that may interfere with function of anorectum
